Guyett's Paranoid Geology Trip


reviewed by Llamafluff, mykonian and callforjudgement.
Backup modded by Antihero


13 of you head out on an awesome field trip to the Isle of Arran in Scotland. The isle of Arran is an excellent place to learn about geology and have bitching parties at night time. Each day your field trip organiser, Guyett, brings you out in the field to explore the island but he heads to bed early and lets the students stay up drinking. Unfortunately there are some amongst you that are not real Geologists (Town).... There are Geographers (Mafia) amongst the crowd for you to find. The Geographers are notorious dry shites and are aiming to whittle down the numbers.

RULES - Please read carefully

(shamelessly stolen and modified from Maestro)
* This is my color. Don't use my colour.
* You are expected to be an active participant in this game. Players who have not posted for 2 days [48 hours] will be prodded for inactivity.
* After a prod is sent, players have 1 days [24 hours] to respond IN-THREAD in some way, or I will start searching for a replacement.
* If, at any time, a player has received 3 prods for inactivity, I may or may not issue another prod. I will start searching for a replacement.

* If you would like to request replacement or declare V/LA at any time, please PM me.
* If you have a personal problem with another player's activity/posting, please PM me.

* Days will be 2 weeks [14 days] in length. Deadline exceptions will only be made in extremely rare circumstances.
* Nights will be 2 days [48 hours] in length. Night deadline exceptions will only be made to accomodate Nighttime replacements.

* Votes will only be counted if they are in a format such as Vote: Guyett or VOTE: Guyett and must be on a separate line of text and outside of any spoiler tag. (I will not be held accountable for having missed your vote if this rule is not adhered to.)
* Unvotes are nice but not necessary.

* You MAY vote for the option to "No Lynch".
* If "No Lynch" has the most votes at deadline or receives a majority at any point, there will be "No Lynch".
* This is the only way to achieve a "No Lynch" - regular lynching is achieved through plurality. (The first one with the most votes at deadline is lynched.)

* You may not quote anything from a mod that has not been made public

* Upon being Lynched or dying overnight, players may make one "Bah!"-type post after they are officially dead. This post may not contain game-related information or any knowledge they may have of the game's setup or the other players. This rule will be enforced by a Modkill or other action that would harm the offending player's faction.

AND FINALLY:

I am aware that I make mistakes. Please PM me about any I may make or address me in bold in-thread.
Do not hash out issues with me in-thread unless the entire playerlist would benefit.

Vanilla Townie Role PM

Welcome to Guyett's Paranoid Geology Field Trip, XXX!

You are a Town aligned Vanilla Townie.

Abilities

You have no special abilities beyond the right to vote.

Win condition

You win when all threats to the Town have been eliminated and at least one member of the Town remains standing.

The game thread is here. Please confirm in the game thread.

Role Pm's going out now
All role PMs have been sent! Please confirm in-thread. Votes placed prior to day start will not be counted. Once 10/13 have confirmed, the game will start. Any players not confirmed by the confirmation deadline will be replaced before Day 1 begins.

The deadline for confirmation is Tuesday, December 11, 2013 at 19:00 GMT, which is in (expired on 2013-12-11 19:00:00).

The very last bit of the beach is all red sandstone from the Permian. This is all aeolian sandstone, that means the sand was deposited in a desert environment... so this wet horrible part of Scotland was once under a desert approximately 280 million years ago. On the other side of the island in Permian sediment there is trace fossil footprints of type of creature that one of the forerunners of the dinosaurs, but thats a story for another votecount.
Some of the coolest features at this section of beach are the fulgurites. Fulgurites are essentially fossilized lightning strikes!!! They are formed when lightning strikes sand. Modern examples can be found around the world in deserts but apparently the best place to find them is in golf courses where lightning has hit a bunker

Upon cracking open some of the boulders at the base of the cliff with your trusty rock hammer you find something very interesting contained inside. Some of the boulders have a predominately fine black center with blobs of coarse grey minerals and others are mostly coarse grey with small packages of black fine minerals. This is due to mixing of two different magma sources, the coarse one a quartz feldspar porphyry and the fine black one a dolomite. This is interesting as the quartz feldspar porphyry is felsic in origin and the dolomite is mafic in origin... more info at the next VC

Felsic and mafic are two end members of the magma scale. The darker a volcanic rock is the more mafic it is. This is due to the higher % of magnesium. A more felsic rock will have almost no magnesium instead having more aluminium and potassium. The silica content is also much much higher in felsic rocks than mafic rocks. The total alkali silica plot below shows tells how mafic or felsic a rock is. Mafic rocks are much less evolved than felsic rocks, the mafic ones are commonly found at sea floor spreading zones like the Mid Atlantic Ridge as basalts and felsic rocks are most commonly found on continental plates in the form of granites (Rhyolite is chemically the same as granite but it is volcanic rather than plutonic).

First stop of the day is Rubha Airigh Bheirg (pronounced like rubbery veg) to the West of the island. We are stopping here to look at some low grade metamorphic rocks. The rocks here show evidence of multiple metamorphic events and are part of a type of rock found through Scotland and Ireland known as the Dalradian metasediments. There appears to be overprinting on the rocks, this is known as cleavage. It is slightly difficult to distinguish between bedding and cleavage in the field but the diagram below shows how this is done. The bedding is the purple and yellow sections and as it is compressed the rocks fold. Cleavage is a type of linear deformation that shows the orientation of the fold axis. At Rubha Airigh Bheirg the cleavage and bedding appears to be very random but by plotting information on a stereonet it is possible to make sense of what is going on.... more at the next VC.

I did promise a short bit on stereonets... I'll keep is very short as they're complicated and people find them confusing.
Basically they are a flattened circle that able to look like it is in 3d. The image below shows the stereonet with some data plotted on it. Each line corresponds to the strike and dip of some bedding plane. The dip is the direction the bed is angled towards with the angle as well, shallow dipping bedding is almost horizontal and will be quite a wide circular line on the stereonet whereas a steeply dipping bed will be almost vertical and the line will plot close to the center of the circle. The strike is simple 90 degrees from the direction of the dip of the bed.




Next stop is at a location called Lochranza, this is the first of our bonus extra stops. You deserve it after steronets.
Within a 5 minute walk of Locranza is a place known as Hutton's Unconformity. James Hutton is considered one of the fathers of modern geology and this is one of the locations where he found examples to back up his theories (another location will be seen tomorrow). Before Hutton people had a very poor idea on how old the Earth was, Hutton saw these rocks and deduced that because one set of rocks must be considerably older than the other set of rocks the Earth must be considerably older than was originally thought. The image below shows Hutton's Unconformity with 2 distinct rock types, the older has been tilted to around 45 degrees and eroded away with later rock being deposited at a much different angle as seen below

In post 210, Guyett wrote:


The very last bit of the beach is all red sandstone from the Permian. This is all aeolian sandstone, that means the sand was deposited in a desert environment... so this wet horrible part of Scotland was once under a desert approximately 280 million years ago. On the other side of the island in Permian sediment there is trace fossil footprints of type of creature that one of the forerunners of the dinosaurs, but thats a story for another votecount.
Some of the coolest features at this section of beach are the fulgurites. Fulgurites are essentially fossilized lightning strikes!!! They are formed when lightning strikes sand. Modern examples can be found around the world in deserts but apparently the best place to find them is in golf courses where lightning has hit a bunker

Spoiler: fulgurite
